title: Midinfrared photoluminescence of InAsSb quantum dots grown by liquid phase epitaxy. .
abstract: Photoluminescence in the 2–5 µm spectral region is reported from InAs1–xSbx quantum dots grown from the liquid phase at 580 °C on an InAs (100) substrate. Atomic force microscopy shows that coalesced quantum dots and then isolated quantum dots are formed with increasing Sb composition (x = 0.2–0.3) and strain. The 4 K photoluminescence of the isolated and coalesced quantum dots was observed to peak in the midinfrared at 289 and 316 meV, (4.29 and 3.92 µm), respectively. These peaks are due to type II transitions and begin to quench at temperatures above 100 K as holes become thermally activated out of the quantum dot confinement potential. ©2000 American Institute of Physics

APPLIED PHYSICS LETTERS VOLUME 77, NUMBER 23 4 DECEMBER 2000Midinfrared photoluminescence of InAsSb quantum dots grown
by liquid phase epitaxy
A. Krier,a) X. L. Huang, and A. Hammiche
Department of Physics, Lancaster University, Lancaster LA1 4YB, United Kingdom
~Received 27 June 2000; accepted for publication 29 September 2000!
Photoluminescence in the 2–5 mm spectral region is reported from InAs12xSbx quantum dots grown
from the liquid phase at 580 °C on an InAs ~100! substrate. Atomic force microscopy shows that
coalesced quantum dots and then isolated quantum dots are formed with increasing Sb composition
(x50.2– 0.3) and strain. The 4 K photoluminescence of the isolated and coalesced quantum dots
was observed to peak in the midinfrared at 289 and 316 meV, ~4.29 and 3.92 mm!, respectively.
These peaks are due to type II transitions and begin to quench at temperatures above 100 K as holes
become thermally activated out of the quantum dot confinement potential. © 2000 American
Institute of Physics. @S0003-6951~00!04248-0#InAs and its alloys are promising materials for the fab-
rication of mid-infrared ~2–5 mm! optoelectronic devices for
use in gas sensors and many other applications.1 There is
increasing interest in accessing this spectral region using a
variety of materials engineering approaches and techniques.
In recent years, InSb, GaSb, AlSb, and InAs quantum dots
~QDs! have been grown on GaSb and GaAs substrates by
molecular beam epitaxy ~MBE! and metalorganic vapor
phase epitaxy ~MOVPE!. The resulting photoluminescence
emission from these quantum dots was however observed in
the near infrared.2–7 By comparison there have been no re-
ports of InSb or InAs12xSbx quantum dots exhibiting emis-
sion in the spectral range .2 mm. In this letter we report on
the photoluminescence and morphology of InAs12xSbx
quantum dots (x50.2– x50.3) encapsulated in InAs and the
effect of strain as the Sb composition was increased laterally
along the InAs substrate.
A schematic diagram of the type II InAs12xSbx /InAs
quantum dot system is shown in Fig. 1. The photolumines-
cence of InAs is normally dominated by transitions between
shallow donors Es , deep donors ED , and deep acceptors
(EA1 and EA2). At low temperature, the PL of undoped and
n-type InAs generally shows two peaks A and B. However,
additional peaks C and D corresponding to the transitions
from ED to Ev and from Es to EA2, are observed in p-type
material.8 The system affords deep hole confinement (Ev
;100 meV) in the quantum dot based on band offset consid-
erations.
The samples for this investigation were grown from the
liquid phase using a modified ~rapid slider! liquid phase ep-
itaxy ~LPE! technique,9 which is capable of producing quan-
tum wells and quantum dots.10 Under lattice matched growth
conditions continuous ultrathin layers ~quantum wells! are
obtained, but when highly mismatched, quantum dots are
produced instead. In the present investigation InAs12xSbx
quantum dots with x;0.2 were grown on n-type ~S doped
131018 cm23) InAs~100! substrates. Samples of both InAs
encapsulated and unencapsulated InAs12xSbx quantum dots
a!Electronic mail: a.krier@lancaster.ac.uk3790003-6951/2000/77(23)/3791/3/$17.00were grown for photoluminescence ~PL! and atomic force
microscope ~AFM! investigation, respectively. The InAs
buffer and encapsulation layers were grown from an In-rich
melt, whereas the InAs12xSbx was grown from a pseudobi-
nary melt. The resulting quantum dot layer composition (x
;0.2) was calculated from the InAs12xSbx phase diagram.11
The PL sample was grown at 580 °C with a ramp cooling
rate of 0.3 °C/min and using contact times of 300 s, 1 ms,
and 20 s for the InAs buffer, InAsSb quantum dot, and InAs
capping layers, respectively. All three layers were grown us-
ing 25 °C melt supercooling. The total thickness of the PL
sample was ;16 mm and the cap layer thickness was
;1 mm. The corresponding sample for AFM investigation
was grown using similar conditions, but without the encap-
sulation layer. A Topometrix TMX 2000 Explorer AFM was
used to investigate the resulting morphology and to obtain
the fundamental parameters of the InAs12xSbx quantum dots
at different positions ~along the passing direction of the melt!
FIG. 1. Schematic diagram showing the type II InAs12xSbx /InAs encapsu-
lated quantum dot. ~Energy level assignments are based on literature values
where available, confined levels are approximate.!1 © 2000 American Institute of Physics
3792 Appl. Phys. Lett., Vol. 77, No. 23, 4 December 2000 Krier, Huang, and Hammicheacross the substrate. The corresponding low temperature PL
spectra were excited using a 5 W ~514 nm wavelength!
argon-ion laser and detected using a 77 K InSb photodiode
detector and conventional 4 K PL spectroscopy apparatus for
the mid-IR. With this arrangement excitation is indirect,
most of the photoexcited carriers are generated within the
InAs capping layer and diffuse deeper into the sample where
they then recombine within the quantum dots.
Figure 2 shows three AFM images ~a!, ~b!, and ~c! taken
from the sample in regions P3 , P5 , and P7 at different po-
sitions along the sample as shown in the inset. Even though
the contact time is very short ~1 ms!, with 25 °C supercool-
ing there is still local depletion of As from the InAs12xSbx
melt at the growth interface, resulting in a variation in solid
composition across the sample along the passing direction of
the melt ~i.e., Sb increases P3 – P7). This means we are con-
veniently able to examine the resulting morphology and pho-
toluminescence properties corresponding to different
InAs12xSbx compositions having different amounts of lattice
mismatch to the InAs substrate. AFM and PL measurements
on an InAs epitaxial control layer grown using the same

InAs12xSbx quantum dots with increasing Sb composition grown by LPE

characteristic of near band edge recombination, and only

Using the above technique, we were able to observe the
onset of three-dimensional growth of isolated quantum dots
from a coalesced ~quantum well! layer as a function of strain.
Consequently, the InAs12xSbx in region P3 has a relatively
small Sb content (x50.2) and associated strain. The AFM
image of P3 shows quite a smooth continuous InAs12xSbx
layer. Some islands about 300 nm in diameter and 100 nm in
height are visible. This means that a strained epilayer covers
most of the area in the vicinity of P3 , but some large dots
have nucleated to help consume the local strain energy. The
image from region P5 (x50.25) shows a relatively uniform
self-assembled layer of coalesced quantum dots with a few
larger islands.2 The coalesced quantum dots are about 150
nm in diameter and 50 nm in height, with an area density of
;53109 cm22. Region P7 has the highest Sb composition
(x50.3) of the three and the AFM image shows isolated
quantum dots, some of which have coalesced together. The
area density of the isolated dots is ;23109 cm22.
Figure 3 shows the 5 K PL spectra measured from the
sample at several different positions P1 – P9 along the wafer,
again corresponding to increasing Sb composition ~where
P3 , P5 , P7 relate approximately to AFM images A, B, C!.
The PL spectra at P1 and P2 show two peaks A and B
located at 418 and 406 meV, corresponding to band–band
transitions ~from Ec to Ev) and donor–acceptor transitions
(Es – EA1) in InAs, respectively. These originate from the
capping and buffer layers but, in the PL at P3 , another peak
~F! located at 378 meV is observed, which correlates with

quantum dots with increasing Sb content from positions P1 to P9 along the
sample. The peaks labeled A–G correspond to the transitions shown in Fig.
1. ~Top curves P1 , P2 , P3 ; middle curves P4 , P5 , P6 ; lower curves P7 ,
P8 , P9).
3793Appl. Phys. Lett., Vol. 77, No. 23, 4 December 2000 Krier, Huang, and Hammichethe InAs12xSbx ‘‘quantum well’’ layer ~shown in the AFM
image at A!. At P2 the ‘‘quantum well’’ layer is thinner than
at P3 and peak F shifts to higher energy and enhances peak
B compared with the PL observed at P1 . In the spectra ob-
served from positions P3 to P7 , peak F shifts from 378 to
316 meV, and decreases in intensity as the 289 meV peak G
increases in intensity. This suggests that as we move across
the sample with increasing Sb composition (x) and hence
strain, the emission is initially representative of a strained
quantum well layer and gradually becomes characteristic of
self-assembled coalesced QDs. Then finally at some critical
composition (x;0.25) PL is observed mainly from isolated
QDs of fixed size at P7 .12 The two dips in the broad peak G
at around 290 meV ~4.3 mm! are due to CO2 absorption in
the laboratory atmosphere. Moving further along from posi-
tion P7 to P9 , peak G decreases in intensity, while the defect
related peak D ~transitions from Es to EA2) and its phonon
replica peak E , as well as peak B increase in intensity. This
is consistent with the overgrowth of the isolated QDs result-
ing in the production of more deep states (EA1 and EA2) in
the InAs in the immediate vicinity outside of the dots which
enhances peaks B and D, as well as introducing recombina-
tion centers ~perhaps at EA4 and EA5) within the quantum dot
to quench peak G.
Figure 4 shows the dependence of emission peak energy
on the laser power for the various PL peaks discussed in Fig.
3 above. The peak F blueshifts from 312.2 to 318.4 meV as
the excitation intensity increases which is consistent with a
type II band alignment for the coalesced QDs.5 The blueshift
of the isolated quantum dots ~peak G! with increasing exci-
tation energy is even larger than that of peak F, consistent
with a smaller density of states in the isolated QDs compared
with the coalesced QDs. The InAs related peaks B(P5) and
B(P7) exhibit only a small blueshift ~1.2 meV! by compari-
FIG. 4. Variation of emission peak energy with increasing laser power for
the principal transitions at 5 K, showing the strong blueshift of the confined
state energies; QD, peak G(P7), and InAs encapsulation peak B(P7).son, consistent with the band-gap recombination. The peak
energy of peak G is about 35 meV lower than that of peak F,
because the confinement in the 3D isolated QDs is stronger
than the 2D confinement in the coalesced dots. The inte-
grated intensity of peak G(P7) also increases almost linearly
with excitation intensity up to 4 W, whereas the intensity of
the InAs related peak shows a strong saturation above 2 W.
The temperature dependence of the integrated intensities
of these PL peaks provides additional evidence of the strong
quantum confinement inside the quantum dots. The PL inten-
sity of the isolated quantum dots, G(P7) increases slightly
from 5 to 80 K before rapidly quenching at a temperature
above 100 K with an activation energy of 89 meV. The
quenching is associated with holes being thermally excited
out of the quantum dot confinement potential shown sche-
matically in Fig. 1. By comparison the integrated intensity of
the InAs-related peak B(P7) quenches rapidly with increas-
ing temperature above 5 K, with an activation energy of only
4.6 meV.
Mid-infrared photoluminescence from InAs12xSbx quan-
tum dots grown by LPE has been observed at 4.3 mm. The
dependence of the resulting PL with increasing Sb composi-
tion and strain revealed distinct peaks at 316 and 289 meV
which resulted from type II transitions originating from coa-
lesced and isolated dots, respectively. The PL emission per-
sisted up to 210 K but began to quench rapidly above 100 K
with an activation energy which corresponds approximately
to the hole confinement energy in the InAs12xSbx quantum
dot.
